sen.j: 足利 家時（あしかが いえとき）は、鎌倉時代中期の鎌倉幕府の御家人である。
sen.e: Ietoki ASHIKAGA was a Gokenin (shogunal retainers) of the Kamakura Bakufu in the middle of the Kamakura Period.
Ietoki ASHIKAGA was a Gokenin (shogunal retainers) of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in the middle of the Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: the Kamakura bakufuとし、bakufuの補足追加、Periodの頭文字を小文字に変更しました。
sen.e: Ietoki ASHIKAGA was a Gokenin (shogunal retainers) of the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) in the middle of the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 父は足利頼氏、母は上杉重房の娘。
sen.e: His father was Yoriuji ASHIKAGA, and his mother was a daughter of Shigefusa UESUGI.
His father was Yoriuji ASHIKAGA, and his mother was a daughter of Shigefusa UESUGI.
His father was Yoriuji ASHIKAGA, and his mother was a daughter of Shigefusa UESUGI.

sen.j: 重房娘は頼氏の側室であったと考えられ、源頼朝の重臣であった足利義兼以来の北条氏を母としない足利氏当主となった。
sen.e: It is considered that a daughter of Shigefusa was Yoriuji's concubine, and he became the first family head of the Ashikaga clan whose mother was not from the Hojo clan since Yoshikane ASHIKAGA, a senior vassal of MINANOTO no Yoritomo.

It is considered that a daughter of Shigefusa was Yoriuji's concubine, and he became the first family head of the Ashikaga clan whose mother was not from the Hojo clan since Yoshikane ASHIKAGA, a senior vassal of MINANOTO no Yoritomo.

It is considered that a daughter of Shigefusa was Yoriuji's concubine, and he became the first family head of the Ashikaga clan whose mother was not from the Hojo clan since Yoshikane ASHIKAGA, a senior vassal of MINANOTO no Yoritomo.

sen.j: 家時の活動の初見は文永3年（1266年）に被官倉持忠行に袖判下文を与えたことである。
sen.e: He first appeared in the historical materials, when he granted hikan (low-level bureaucrat), 倉持忠行, sodehan kudashibumi (document issued by a superior or office with a signature ("han") in the right hand margin ("sode")).

He first appeared in the historical materials, when he granted hikan (low-level bureaucrat), 倉持忠行, sodehan kudashibumi (document issued by a superior or office with a signature ["han"] in the right hand margin ["sode"]).
sen.cmt: カッコ表記修正しました。
sen.e: He first appeared in the historical materials, when he granted hikan (low-level bureaucrat), 倉持忠行, sodehan kudashibumi (document issued by a superior or office with a signature ["han"] in the right hand margin ["sode"]).

sen.j: この時は7歳程度であったと考えられる。
sen.e: He was around seven years old at this time.
He was around seven years old at that time.
sen.cmt: at this time→at that timeとしました。
sen.e: He was around seven years old at that time.

sen.j: 文永6年（1269年）氏寺である足利鑁阿寺に寺規を定めるなど、興隆に力を注いでいる。
sen.e: In 1269, he contributed his energy to prosper his Uji-dera Temple (temple built for praying clan's glory), Ashikaga Banna-ji Temple by establishing rules of this temple.
In 1269, he contributed his energy to prosper his Uji-dera Temple (temple built for praying clan's glory), Ashikaga Banna-ji Temple by establishing rules of this temple.
In 1269, he contributed his energy to prosper his Uji-dera Temple (temple built for praying clan's glory), Ashikaga Banna-ji Temple by establishing rules of this temple.

sen.j: この頃には叔父であり家督代行であったと考えられる斯波氏の祖足利家氏が引退して、家時が正式に家督となったと思われる。
sen.e: Around this time, after the ancestor of the Shiba clan, Ieuji Ashikaga who were thought to be his uncle and the acting head of the family retired, it is considered that Ietoki officially became the head of the family.

Around that time, after the ancestor of the Shiba clan, Ieuji ASHIKAGA who is thought to have been his uncle and the acting head of the family retired, it is considered that Ietoki officially became the head of the family.
sen.cmt: Around this time→Around that time、Ieuji Ashikaga→Ieuji ASHIKAGA、who were thought to be→who is thought to have beenに修正しました。
sen.e: Around that time, after the ancestor of the Shiba clan, Ieuji ASHIKAGA who is thought to have been his uncle and the acting head of the family retired, it is considered that Ietoki officially became the head of the family.

sen.j: 文永10年（1273年）に高野山金剛三昧院の僧法禅と所領を巡って訴訟となって争ったが、弘安2年（1279年）に敗訴している。
sen.e: In 1273, he disputed over shoryo (territory) with Hozen, a priest of Kongosanmaiin Temple in Mt.Koya, however, he lost the case in 1279.
In 1273, he disputed over shoryo (territory) with Hozen, a priest of Kongosanmai-in Temple on Mt.Koya; however, he lost the case in 1279.
sen.cmt: Kongosanmai-in Templeとし、in Mt. Koya→on Mt. Koyaに修正、カンマ→セミコロンに変更しました。
sen.e: In 1273, he disputed over shoryo (territory) with Hozen, a priest of Kongosanmai-in Temple on Mt.Koya; however, he lost the case in 1279.

sen.j: この頃、鎌倉幕府内では執権北条時宗の公文所執事（内管領）であった平頼綱と御家人の実力者であり幕府の重臣であった安達泰盛の争いが激化した。
sen.e: At the time, conflict between TAIRA no Yoritsuna who was Kumonjo Shitsuji (a steward of administration office) for the regent Tokimune HOJO in Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and Yasumori ADACHI who was the influential shogunal retainer and a chief vassal of Bakufu became intensified, and after the death of Tokimune, an armed conflict referred to as the Shimotsuki Incident occurred in November, 1825, and after Yasumori died in a losing cause, Yoritsuna's despotic government started.

At the time, conflict between TAIRA no Yoritsuna who was Kumonjo Shitsuji (a steward of administration office) for the regent Tokimune HOJO in the Kamakura bakufu and Yasumori ADACHI who was the influential shogunal retainer and a chief vassal of the bakufu became intensified.
sen.cmt: 「一原文一訳文の例外対処」the Kamakura bakufu、the bakufuとし、既出のため補足削除しました。
sen.e: At the time, conflict between TAIRA no Yoritsuna who was Kumonjo Shitsuji (a steward of administration office) for the regent Tokimune HOJO in the Kamakura bakufu and Yasumori ADACHI who was the influential shogunal retainer and a chief vassal of the bakufu became intensified.

sen.j: 時宗没後の弘安8年（1285年）11月には霜月騒動と呼ばれる武力衝突が起こり、泰盛は敗死し、以後頼綱の専制政治が始まる。
sen.e: After the death of Tokimune, an armed conflict referred to as the Shimotsuki Incident occurred in November, 1825 (December, 1825 in new calendar); as a result Yasumori lost and died, and Yoritsuna's despotic government started afterward.
sen.cmt: 「一原文一訳文の例外対処」and削除、「弘安8年（1285年）11月」→「霜月騒動」のため旧暦表記のままとし、カッコ内に新暦を併記、一部訳し直しました。
sen.e: After the death of Tokimune, an armed conflict referred to as the Shimotsuki Incident occurred in November, 1825 (December, 1825 in new calendar); as a result Yasumori lost and died, and Yoritsuna's despotic government started afterward.

sen.j: 足利氏はこの頃泰盛に接近し、霜月騒動では一族吉良氏の足利上総三郎（吉良満氏か）が泰盛に与同している。
sen.e: The Ashikaga clan approached Yasumori at the time and Kazusa no Saburo ASHIKAGA (Mitsuuji KIRA) from the Kira clan, agreed with and assisted Yasumori during the Shimotsuki Incident.

The Ashikaga clan approached Yasumori at the time and Kazusa no Saburo ASHIKAGA (believed to be Mitsuuji KIRA) from the Kira clan of the Ashikaga family, agreed with and assisted Yasumori during the Shimotsuki Incident.
sen.cmt: (Mitsuuji KIRA)→(believed to be Mitsuuji KIRA)とし、「一族」(足利氏一族と思われます)→訳漏れのため訳出しました。
sen.e: The Ashikaga clan approached Yasumori at the time and Kazusa no Saburo ASHIKAGA (believed to be Mitsuuji KIRA) from the Kira clan of the Ashikaga family, agreed with and assisted Yasumori during the Shimotsuki Incident.

sen.j: 家時は前年弘安7年（1284年）6月25日に亡くなっているが、これは泰盛の強力な与党であった北条一門佐介時国の失脚に関連して自害したのではないか、とされる。
sen.e: Ietoki died on August 14, 1284, the year before the Shimotsuki Incident, and it is considered that he might commit suicide in connection with downfall of Tokikuni SASUKE from Hojo family who was a powerful comrade of Yasumori.

Ietoki died on August 14, 1284, the year before the Shimotsuki Incident, and it is considered that he might have committed suicide in connection with downfall of Tokikuni SASUKE from the Hojo family who was a powerful comrade of Yasumori.
sen.cmt: might commit→might have committed、the Hojo familyとしました。
sen.e: Ietoki died on August 14, 1284, the year before the Shimotsuki Incident, and it is considered that he might have committed suicide in connection with downfall of Tokikuni SASUKE from the Hojo family who was a powerful comrade of Yasumori.

sen.j: 墓所は鎌倉に功臣山報国寺 (鎌倉市)で、家時は開基とされるが、報国寺の開基は南北朝期の上杉重兼である。
sen.e: His graveyard is located in Hokoku-ji Temple in Koshinzan (Kamakura City), and it is considered that Ietoki was Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding), however, Kaiki of Hokoku-ji Temple was Shigekane UESUGI in the Northern and Southern Dynasties period.

His graveyard is located in Koshinzan Hokoku-ji Temple (Kamakura City), and it is considered that Ietoki was Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding); however, Kaiki of Hokoku-ji Temple was Shigekane UESUGI in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.
sen.cmt: Hokoku-ji Temple in Koshinzan→Koshinzan Hokoku-ji Temple、the Northern and Southern Dynasties period→the period of the Northern and Southern Courtsとし、カンマ→セミコロンに変更しました。
sen.e: His graveyard is located in Koshinzan Hokoku-ji Temple (Kamakura City), and it is considered that Ietoki was Kaiki (patron of a temple in its founding); however, Kaiki of Hokoku-ji Temple was Shigekane UESUGI in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts.

sen.j: 家時と関係の深い上杉氏が供養したのであろう。
sen.e: It is thought that the Uesugi clan who was closely-linked to Ietoki held a memorial service.
It is thought that the Uesugi clan who was closely-linked to Ietoki held a memorial service.
It is thought that the Uesugi clan who was closely-linked to Ietoki held a memorial service.

sen.j: 足利氏には、先祖に当たる平安時代の源義家が書き残したという、「自分は七代の子孫に生まれ変わって天下を取る」という内容の置文が存在する。
sen.e: In "Nan-Taiheiki" (a critique of the historical epic "Taiheiki") written by Sadayo (Ryoshun) IMAGAWA, it is described that the Ashikaga clan had Okibumi (Will and Testament) "I will be reincarnated as a seventh-generation descendant and reign over the whole country" that was written and left behind by their ancestor, MINAMOTO no Yoshiie, however, Yoshiie's seventh-generation descendant, Ietoki, thought that he couldn't carry out this, therefore, he prayed to Hachiman Daibosatsu for that descendant of three generations after him conquer the country and killed himself with leaving ganmon (Shinto or Buddhist prayer (read) behind, and Takauji ASHIKAGA and his younger brother Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA saw this Ganmon with their own eyes and Sadayo also saw this Ganmon.

In the "Nan-Taiheiki" (a critique of the historical epic "Taiheiki") written by Sadayo (Ryoshun) IMAGAWA, it is described that the Ashikaga clan had an Okibumi, "I will be reincarnated as a seventh-generation descendant and reign over the whole country" that was written and left behind by their ancestor, MINAMOTO no Yoshiie in the Heian period; however, Yoshiie's seventh-generation descendant, Ietoki, thought that he could not carry out this, therefore, he prayed to Hachiman Daibosatsu for descendants of three generations after him conquering the country and killed himself with leaving a Ganmon (Shinto or Buddhist prayer) behind, and Takauji ASHIKAGA and his younger brother Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA saw the Ganmon with their own eyes and Sadayo also saw the Ganmon.
sen.cmt: 「平安時代の」→訳漏れのため訳出、In the "Nan-Taiheiki"、an Okibumiとし、既出のため補足を削除、カンマ追加、カンマ→セミコロンに変更、couldn't→could not、ganmon→a Ganmonとし、補足の一部を修正、for that descendant of three generations after him conquer→for descendants of three generations after him conquering、this Ganmon→the Ganmonとしました。
sen.e: The Ashikaga clan had an Okibumi left behind by MINAMOTO no Yoshiie, their ancestor, in the Heian period which was as follows: "I will be reincarnated as a seventh-generation descendant and reign over the whole country."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理内容を修正しました。

sen.j: 義家の七代の子孫にあたる家時は、自分の代では達成できないため、八幡大菩薩に三代後の子孫に天下を取らせよと祈願し、願文を残して自害した。
sen.e: However, Ietoki, Yoshiie's seventh-generation descendant, thought that he could not achieve this, therefore, he prayed to Great Bodhisattava Hachiman to help the third generation descendant of him to conquer the whole country, and killed himself with a ganmon (a written wish) left behind.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理内容を修正しました。

sen.j: 足利尊氏や弟の足利直義はこれを実見し、今川貞世（了俊）もこれを見たと、貞世の著作である『難太平記』には記されている。
sen.e: Takauji ASHIKAGA and his younger brother Tadayoshi ASHIKAGA saw the ganmon with their own eyes and so did Sadayo (Ryoshun) IMAGAWA according to "Nan-Taiheiki" (a critique of the historical epic "Taiheiki") written by himself.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外処理内容を修正しました。

sen.j: 尊氏と直義は家時から三代の子孫にあたり、鎌倉幕府を滅ぼして、後醍醐天皇の建武政権樹立に多大な貢献をした。
sen.e: Takauji and Tadayoshi who were descendants of three generations after Ietoki conquered Kamakura Bakufu and made significant contributions to establish the Kenmu government of Emperor Godaigo, however, after they went down to Kamakura to suppress the war without the Emperor's permission when Tokuyuki HOJO, the son of the last Tokuso, Takatoki HOJO started Nakasendai War and occupied Kamakura, they broke away from the Kenmu government and started the movement to establish the samurai government again.
Takauji and Tadayoshi, who were descendants of three generations after Ietoki, conquered the Kamakura bakufu and made significant contributions to establish the Kenmu government of Emperor Godaigo.
sen.cmt: 「一原文一訳文の例外対処」カンマ追加、the Kamakura bakufuとしました。
sen.e: Takauji and Tadayoshi, who were descendants of three generations after Ietoki, conquered the Kamakura bakufu and made significant contributions to establish the Kenmu government of Emperor Godaigo.

sen.j: しかし、最後の得宗北条高時の子北条時行が中先代の乱を起こして鎌倉を占拠したのに対し、天皇に無断で鎌倉に下って乱を平定したのを機に、建武政権から離反して再び武家政権を樹立する運動を開始している。
sen.e: However, after they went down to Kamakura to suppress the war without the Emperor's permission when Tokiyuki HOJO, the son of the last Tokuso (the patrimonial head of the main branch of the Hojo clan), Takatoki HOJO started the Nakasendai War and occupied Kamakura, they broke away from the Kenmu government and started the movement to establish the samurai government again.
sen.cmt: 「一原文一訳文の例外対処」Tokuyuki HOJO→Tokiyuki HOJOに修正、Tokusoの補足追加 (用語集参照)、the Nakasendai Warとしました。
sen.e: However, after they went down to Kamakura to suppress the war without the Emperor's permission when Tokiyuki HOJO, the son of the last Tokuso (the patrimonial head of the main branch of the Hojo clan), Takatoki HOJO started the Nakasendai War and occupied Kamakura, they broke away from the Kenmu government and started the movement to establish the samurai government again.

sen.j: 家時の願文が尊氏挙兵の動機とも考えられている。
sen.e: It is believed that Ietoki's Ganmon led Takauji to raise an army.
It is believed that Ietoki's Ganmon led Takauji to raise an army.
It is believed that Ietoki's Ganmon led Takauji to raise an army.

sen.j: 家時の置文には偽作説も唱えられているが、家時が執事高師氏に遣わした書状を、師氏の孫で尊氏の執事となった高師直の甥である高師秋が所持しており、直義がこれを見て感激し、師秋には直義が直筆の案文を送って正文は自分の下に留め置いた、という文書が残っている。
sen.e: Some people said that Ietoki's okibumi was a fake, however, there is monjo (written material) described that Moroaki KO who was a nephew of Moronao KO, a grandson of Morouji and Takauji's steward had the letter that Ietoki sent to Morouji KO, and Tadayoshi was deeply moved when he saw this letter and Tadayoshi sent his own writing draft of this letter to Moroaki and kept the official text of this letter on hand.

Some people said that Ietoki's Okibumi was a fake; however, there is a monjo (written material) described that KO no Moroaki who was a nephew of KO no Moronao, a grandson of Morouji and Takauji's steward, had the letter that Ietoki sent to his steward KO no Morouji, and Tadayoshi was deeply moved when he saw the letter and Tadayoshi sent his own writing draft of the letter to Moroaki and kept the official text of the letter on hand.
sen.cmt: 「執事」→訳漏れのため訳出、表記統一のため、okibumi→Okibumiとし、カンマ→セミコロンに変更、monjo→a monjo、Moroaki KO→KO no Moroaki、Moronao KO→KO no Moronao、Morouji KO→KO no Morouji、this letter→the letterとし、カンマ追加しました。
sen.e: Some people said that Ietoki's Okibumi was a fake; however, there is a monjo (written material) described that KO no Moroaki who was a nephew of KO no Moronao, a grandson of Morouji and Takauji's steward, had the letter that Ietoki sent to his steward KO no Morouji, and Tadayoshi was deeply moved when he saw the letter and Tadayoshi sent his own writing draft of the letter to Moroaki and kept the official text of the letter on hand.

sen.j: これが『難太平記』のいう置文と同一のものであったかは不明である。
sen.e: It is unknown that this letter is the same as Okibumi described in "Nan-Taiheiki."
It is unknown that this letter is the same as the Okibumi described in the "Nan-Taiheiki."
It is unknown that this letter is the same as the Okibumi described in the "Nan-Taiheiki."
